features.title: AWS
features.description: Amazon Web Services (AWS) is a secure cloud services platform, offering compute power, database storage, content delivery and other functionality to help businesses scale and grow.

features.title: Google Cloud
features.description: Google Cloud Platform is a suite of public cloud computing services offered by Google. The platform includes a range of hosted services for compute, storage and application development that run on Google hardware.

features.title: Azure
features.description: Azure is a public cloud computing platform—with solutions including Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS), Platform as a Service (PaaS), and Software as a Service (SaaS) that can be used for services such as analytics, virtual computing, storage, networking, and much more.

features.title: Docker
features.description: Docker is a set of platform as a service products that use OS-level virtualization to deliver software in packages called containers. Containers are isolated from one another and bundle their own software, libraries and configuration files; they can communicate with each other through well-defined channels

features.title: Kubernetes
features.description: Kubernetes is an open-source container-orchestration system for automating application deployment, scaling, and management. It was originally designed by Google, and is now maintained by the Cloud Native Computing Foundation

features.title: Cloud Native Infrastructure
features.description: Cloud-native infrastructure is the hardware and software that runs and supports the applications that are built to draw on the cloud’s advantages, and that only exist in the cloud. The same principles can be used to modernize legacy applications, though it is debatable if those applications can be truly considered cloud-native.
